text: hi everyone used to be Fant anno here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for review of the new Thom
Yorke record tomorrow's modern boxes
Thom Yorke singer-songwriter
multi-instrumentalist producer famed
frontman of Radiohead one of the most
significant musical acts of the 2000s
there's not really anything that can be
said about their early and definitive
years that hasn't already been written
broadcast each tin to stone
but Radiohead's latest output has kind
of been consumed by the band's
attraction to or maybe even just Thom
Yorke's attraction to electronics most
famously on the latest full-length LP
the King of Limbs which drew quite a few
comparisons from Tommy works first solo
endeavor the eraser the beats the
instrumentals on this LP were pretty
stiff pretty lifeless in comparison with
a lot of Radiohead's other material
however Thom Yorke followed this project
up pretty quickly with another project
Atoms for Peace the record he dropped
through that project amok seemed like a
much more well-put-together version of
what was going on on the King of Limbs
in my opinion some of the tracks off
these two records I like some of them I
don't my views on these albums are a
little mixed I think Tom loves the
explorative qualities of electronic
music the complexities of electronic
music as do I which is why I follow a
lot of his forays into this stuff but
sometimes Tom really fails to make this
genre come to life for me because the
end result when he produces something is
typically very static and kind of
lifeless and maybe that's part of the
reason he feels so attracted to these
sounds the lack of humanity the lack of
an organic feel however I can't say in
the case of Tom's music it's something I
vibe with 100% even if he does manage to
drop a real sense of melancholy and
introspection in these songs from the
King of Limbs I thought amok was a step
forward and in my opinion I think
tomorrow's modern boxes is kind of like
a step back
I think it's self-serving synthetic
sadness compositionally I think these
tracks are a little less flesh
out than the material on amok and maybe
even the King of Limbs in comparison I
would say even a tad unimaginative there
are lots of very dry frigid beats and
since sequences on this LP and at times
the synthesizer leads the bass lines the
rhythms they barely feel like they're
syncing up or complementing one another
kind of like on the track there's no ice
for my drink which is a relatively
soulless instrumental there's a little
very faint vocal accompaniment on this
track not really anything lyric wise to
be offered but this song is sort of in
the minority on this very short album
the majority of the tracks on this LP
actually has Thom Yorke's vocals being
very upfront very clear tom is
delivering more of his typically nasal
crooning but very few of these songs are
actually that well developed you do have
songs like the intro here which kicks
off with a pretty great beat but it
doesn't really progress into anything
that significantly interesting or you do
have songs that are really stripped back
and skeletal and with the chord
progressions and the melodies the vocal
melodies they may be pretty appealing
there's like a serious tune at the core
of this song but instrumentally tom
doesn't really build things up beyond
the very sparse simple tune that he
offers it's like these songs are either
suffering from debilitating depression
or just a little writer's block or just
the couldn't be bothered blues I like
the aesthetic of this album I like the
sense of place this album has but it's
sort of like being rocketed into space
without any of the fun or excitement or
newness of actually being in space again
I do like the aesthetic of this album
and there are parts musically that do
stand out to me again with chord
progressions sort of like the closer the
vocal melody on this track is really
great as well then there is brain in a
bottle which it's got a great beat but
it doesn't move on anything more
interesting beyond the intro the song
interference which I think is my
favorite song on this record sounds like
it could have made for a great intro or
for a great song at the core of a track
on a record like kid a and the song
truth ray is actually stunningly
beautiful as well I loved the way that
the chords just drone throughout that
entire track it's just intoxicating ly
sad most of this a
song no hype no pressure dropped out of
nowhere album isn't that bad
it's not that great either some of its
good some of its just glaringly boring
Thom Yorke here is just kind of
indulging in a bit of digital diddling
the results are mixed but I wouldn't
mind listening to it again I'm feeling a
strong five to a light six on this thing
transition if you've given this record
to listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it
Anthony Fantana Thom Yorke tomorrow's
modern boxes forever
